comments.body: Yeah I did this manually through a resource pack a while ago, it's kind of a long process, but it's possible to modify any of the in game songs, adding new ones, removing some, and even changing the pre-existing track to a different song.
Aria
Aria math is legit one of the best theme songs in the world and it should be in survival mode too and a quite suggestion from me is that please hier C418 again for new songs like this. Thanks

This. I've been wishing for years that it would play in Survival. And I think it should be more common in Creative Mode, at least on Java Edition. It has a 1/6 chance to play on Bedrock, and roughly a 1/28 chance on Java. For a while, I thought it only played on Bedrock since I went half a year without hearing it on Java after I got a computer.

Aria Math belongs in Survival Minecraft because it captures the game’s true spirit — beauty, struggle, and quiet wonder. Its haunting melody fits moments of exploration, danger, and reflection, not just endless creativity. In Survival, it deepens emotion and atmosphere, turning ordinary gameplay into something meaningful, reminding players why Minecraft feels alive and timeless.
Aria math exclusively in Creative mode should be a terrible crime paid with 3 life sentences

Love this. A crimson fruit/"pod" which is an excellent food source but deals one damage on consumption would be super fun for hardcore nether survival challenges. Twisted pods could cause nausea or even poison. The roots should drop "spores" or "sprouts" instead of seeds. Netherwart also needs to be remastered to grow on soul soil.
Even better, what if bats spawned on a block in the nether and had the same use for farming in the nether as bees currently do in the overworld?
I agree with this, but not the lava part. Perhaps a better way of adding this would be to have a new liquid, or just have the crops work like nether wart.
This would make building a base in the nether a lot more useful.

Have you ever looked at a cold water bottle on a hot day… I feel cauldrons should be used as a catalyst for farming in the nether. With a cauldron allowing dirt block place immediately next to it the minimum amount of moisture to farm (4 total blocks of farm land max. The immediate blocks next to the cauldron) and no other change. (Reason: as hot gases condensate on cold surfaces suck as an iron pot with water in it)
Netherrite workstation
This sounds like an issue with render distance. What was your render distance set at?

So what you want is an increased render distance of a beacon beam.  How far away are the places?  It would probably be more effective to build a road between your two cities if you want to be able to travel easily between them.

I wouldn't say the main point of the beacon is to be able to find a place.  The main point is the effects you can get by building a big enough pyramid.

@macchupicchu96 @claygoddesssari

Actually, the player render distance is the same no matter what the render distance is, and it is fairly short, meaning playing with others is actually slightly inconvenient.

Also, in general a 'beacon' is defined as, an obvious or deliberately easy to find marker, so technically speaking a beacon's main purpose is a navigation guide/marker.

I agree. It's especially annoying when you play on an smp with your younger siblings who can't handle hard mode very well, and you have to switch in to hard mode whenever you need to manually convert them... and even worse when a zombie somehow gets in and kills them when you're not even around. Baby Zombies are the worst in this case.

Just switch to Hard mode if you want to make Zombie Villagers. I personally see the 100% chance of Zombie Villagers as a reward for switching to Hard mode. Besides, you can switch back from Hard mode after making Zombie Villagers, so it's not that bad.

But I think that making this a gamerule or an option in the world settings is something I would like to see, so I'm voting on this post.
maybe this conversion should be gamerule instead of hard difficulty

This would improve the SMP experience greatly. Ensuring that the chance is always 100%, or that it at least depends on some in-game mechanism, gives players on servers more control over their experience.

As villager trades are very powerful if converted multiple times, the current implementation makes hard mode actually easier than any other difficulty. Like paying 60 emeralds for a pickaxe on easy, and 1 single emerald on hard.

The Pie chart, in multiplayer situations exposes Enchant tables and bells... making Enchanting on unprotected (not plugged in to protect individual player plots) problematic.

The Pie chart shows chests... making basic storage in these environments problematic.

The Pie chart shows e-chests... making the essential use of them, on these type servers, difficult at best - impossible at worst.

The Pie chart shows conduits, trapped chests, and campfires... dead giveaways of player activity... making them impossible to use.

The Pie chart shows spawners... putting everyone of these at risk of destruction... without having to go to any effort to actually search them out.

While I understand Mojang's mission as regards educating would be programmers, and I understand the value of having a tool both for Mojang and coders of this level of power. In the case of the multiplayer setting this is a tool that is otherwise only obtainable through hacked clients, known as ESP. (Something which I will note, would NOT be allowed - in its hacked client variety - on many multiplayer servers. Something many have banned players for using.) The Pie chart is not a tool required for everyday game play, either in single or in multi player settings, and is far to overpowered in settings where griefing/raiding is either merely accepted, or actively encouraged.

I believe Mojang should reconsider it's inclusion, that should either be removed entirely or at the least, be restricted from showing these details.

On servers where players can do things like PVP in survival mode, this debug feature presents a problem with hiding resources from other players or building "secret bases." People are able to use this pie chart and play with render distance to locate anything that pops up on the various menus: specific mobs, enderchests, shulker boxes, even regular chests. It ruins that aspect of the gameplay.

Also, the number of loaded entities helps on this (that "E: [number/number]"). That can also help locating a base with some sort of legal "cheating". If those 2 could be disabled while reducedDebugInfo is On, for example, would be fascinating (though that also removes coordinates...). Or a better option, just put it optional! Let the server decide if the players can see those 2 or not! At least in survival servers, those 2 are very cheaty... People can find bases very easily with those things without any effort. Not too cool. If they follow us to our base, or accidentally find it, now that's cool. Not with this legal cheats that can't be disabled.
agreed
I agree. This feature is overly harmful to multiplayer servers. Allowing players to cheat and disguise it as using a debug feature. This feature never needed added and it should be removed.

Maybe it could be called "The magic update".  It could add new enchantments, and a new item called the "magic upgrade".  Combining it with an enchanted book in an anvil would raise it by one level.  Every enchantment could go up to level 5.  It could upgrade items past the normal limit.  Upgrading mending would make the item mend more, and upgraded channeling would make the lightning do more damage.  You could also upgrade potions with the magic upgrade and a brewing stand.  Potion effect levels could go up to 5.  Higher levels of water breathing and fire resistance would make water and fire heal you respectively.  The Wither would now drop three magic upgrades along with the nether star.

My Second Idea is: adding the totem of Undying crafting Recipe but make it SUPER EXPENSIVE. So basically the totem of undying recipe should require 18 new recipes which need to be done to gain it Without hunting down evokers. My Third Idea is: add in these ores; Magmastone Ore, Phantom Blood Ore, Blue, Red, Green, Yellow, Orange and White Magicite Ores. And My Fourth and Final Idea is: adding in Ather-like Sky islands that you need a new item for and name the items the cloud gems and then make like a glowstone version of the end portal but with phantom Frames in each corner that requires the gems and a special item called the Sky Tome. And call the 1.20 Update the Mystic Skies update

My ideas for the Minecraft 1.20 update will to be getting more nether in the overworld, I am suggesting to have a Scorched forest, once a lush forest blooming with life, now a deserted and burned landscape deprived of life. Souls of the once living villagers now trapped in light blue glowing apples, these apples can be used to gain more heart than usual. Unfortunately these biomes are super rare only 1 every 25 biomes. These biomes come with a brand new wood type, Ashwood, it may be fragile, but it adds a new color to Minecraft's color wheel of wood. So, what do you say, want to add it?
Yes 100% this could have some fun applications for Redstone, this could be used for lightning/storm detectors for channeling or riptide and have usages in charging creepers and the like.
That could make for some very cool red stone contraptions.
I think it definitely should emit redstone. One of the special things it could do with redstone is emitting a signal that reaches 25-30 blocks because a lightning strike has so much power/energy.
They should add if one lightning is on top and one is at the bottom with a couple of blocks of air that it can create spark gaps too!
This would be cool while still being a very vanilla like feature

I had the same thought! I think this would make mining more fun and interesting. When branch mining, your inventory gets full quickly and you have to travel all the back to your storage system to deposit all the cobble and resources you've gathered, or leave the cobblestone on the floor to despawn. Even if you bring empty shulker boxes you're bound to run out of inventory space eventually.

On my survival world, I was going to set up a minecart rail to carry minecart-chests back to a storage system so I can keep mining uninterrupted. Imagine how cool that would be! Unfortunately, I'm hesitant to continue building this system because I know eventually my storage will be outside the chunks I'm loading and the minecart won't get all the way back.

If minecarts could load chunks I could see people using minecarts for actual mining with a system similar to what I described.

maybe there could be a minecart chunk loading limit to further reduce lag
you also would want to stop people from using this as just a way to load chunks so maybe in the minecarts travel it cant be in a small loop.

Since there is already the dynamic of chunkloading via commands (/tickingarea), you could simply latch on to this concept and implement a sort of dynamic ticking area.

Since there already exists a maximum cap of 10 permanently loaded areas (4 chunks radius maximum each) via the tickkingarea command, giving minecarts the permission to occupy one of these slots would be the way to go. By doing so, a maximum of 10 loaded minecarts would be possible, therefore limiting the possibility of abuse, while at the same time having the ability to send stuff along the rail tracks. Skilled players could get very creative with this dynamic, as this would enable the possibility for sending long range redstone signals as well.

I am currently building a project with friends of mine, outside render/simulation distance of our main base. Sending building supllies from A to B is very exhausting since you need to hitch a ride every time you want to send stuff. Therefore the mechanic is already useable, but with a player character as "dynamic chunk loader", taking away the fun it could provide.

I imagine a scenario where you are able to build a sort of redstone databus, which gives the command to auto load predefined items into a storage cart and have it return to the building site. Since this would surely require advanced expertise i do not see any balance issues. (at least none that are as op as the iron farm lol)

All of the above is based on experience made on minecraft bedrock realms.
Have active furnace minecarts load chunks. This would limit how much chunk loading was going on as well as giving furnace minecarts more of a use.

In general there needs to be an overhaul of how events in unloaded chunks are handled. The current model of "anywhere too far from the player is totally frozen" really limits our creativity in making automated builds that are actually useful. At least for me, this is a major hurdle to playing Minecraft to my best enjoyment, since my playstyle consists in going on adventures far away and returning to my base.

Ideally, this would be some kind of generalized solution that doesn't require hacky chunk loader blocks (like in mods) or just simulating everything, which would obviously be too slow. As a starting point, it could be made so that blocks that have been seen by the player from up close which would reasonably be expected to do something while far away (EG crops that grow, minecarts that move) are added to a separate simulation list and simulated individually (rather than with their entire chunk, to save on resources). When the chunk the block is in is re-entered, its state is updated to whatever it is supposed to be. This would also apply across dimensions.
Here after they made ender pearls load chunks. They should definitely do the same for minecarts. It would be amazing for servers. We could make mail systems!

They could add a new minecart. A copper minecart, a trap chest Minecraft whatever and only those load chunks. Obviously minecarts shouldn't generally do that since that would load so many farms all the time.

They could have a different speed limit too to improve performance. I dont mind waiting - knowing it works reliably and the minecarts arrive would be cool enough

This makes a lot of sense to add to the game mechanically, but the idea might be better serviced with a dedicated crouch along with its own animation. A dedicated crouch may seem impossible for the simple reason that it would be a challenge to add to the console controllers' button layouts, but sprinting while sneaking could be a very natural feeling way of implementing a crouch.

Definitely, since horses can no longer enter boats on Bedrock. Other enchantments could also be used like soul speed, and more typical armour enchantments.
I would be happy with magic protection as an enchantment without a mini-boss. I also support the idea of an exclusive enchanted book added to end city loot.
It should also reduce the effects of harmful potions. Make potion of damaging hurt less, reduce the time negative potion effects affect you.

Don't forget protecting against negative potions being thrown. Perhaps it could even protect against effects that other mobs apply to you reducing the risk of you actually being effected. Essentially it would make it so that when another mob tries to apply an effect to you or a harmful splash potion is thrown at you, it will make it so you have a chance of said potion effect actually coming into effect in the first place with each level increasing your chance of not being effected. For example let's say you have level 1 magic protection and you are attacked by a wither skeleton you would then have 20% chance of the wither effect not effecting you.
I agree with this, but to also reduce potion damage. There's currently no way to avoid being one shot by a harming arrow
